titleStmt.title: The wits academy, or, The muses delight consisting of merry dialogues upon various occasions composed of mirth, wit, and eloquence, for a help to discourse to such as have had but small converse with the critical sort of people, which live in this censorious age : as also, divers sorts of letters upon several occasions both merry and jocose, helpful for the inexpert to imitate, and pleasant to those of better judgement, at their own leisure to peruse : with a perfect collection of all the newest and best songs, and catches, that are, and have been lately in request at court, and both the theatres.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Wits Academy: OR, THE MUSES DELIGHT.

Conſiſting of merry Dialogues upon various occaſions compoſed of Mirth, Wit, and Eloquence, for a help to diſcourſe to ſuch as have had but ſmall converſe with the critical ſort of people, which live in this cenſorious Age.
AS ALSO, Divers ſorts of Letters upon 〈◊〉 occaſions both merry and Jocoſe, helpful for the inexpert to imitate, and pleaſant to thoſe of better Judgement, at their own 〈◊〉 to peruſe.
WITH A perfect Collection of all the neweſt and beſt Songs, and Catches, that are, and have been lately in requeſt at Court, and both the Theatres.
LONDON Printed, and are to be ſold by moſt Bookſellers in London and Weſtminſter. 1 • 77.
Licenſed,

closer.signed: Roger Le' Eſtrange.

div.head: THE EPISTLE DEDICATORY TO THE READER.
div.p:
WHen firſt you caſt an Eye upon the Title Page of this ſmall Volume be not too ſoon cenſorious
in giving judgement to condemnation: for daily errours we do ſee committed, by thoſe that raſhly give their ill opinion of the outward ſhape, ſuggeſting what they do not underſtand; for Fronti nulla Fides, is as true, as that we may obſerve amongst the Spaniſh Gentry, who line their garments with the richeſt Silk, when as the out-ſide is but mean and courſe. The Title of this Book I muſt confeſs is little different
from that piece of weatherbeaten Antiquity, vulgarly known by that once famous Name of, The Academy of Complements; But turn aſide the Frontiſpiece and read, beginning with the Dialogues, and ſo proceed till you have view'd all over, and the reaſon of your miſtake will ſoon be unmaſqu'd, for though Sub ſole nihil novum eſt, yet this you will find to be far different from any other tract
which has preceded of this Nature; exemplary works are for the moſt part very laudable, eſpecially when we make an imitation on thoſe which have been Famous, Learned, and Nobly extracted, &c. Yet in undertakings of this Nature, imitation is only deem'd to be the barren products of a thred-bare Fancy, and that which a Man can't properly call his own. As for the Dialogues and the Letters
which are contained herein, I challenge as my own, ſcarce worth the owning; yet for divertiſement (as it was with me when I writ them) I hope they'l pleaſe you, being either profitable or pleaſant to each capacity. As for the Songs I lay not claim to all of them, for they are a Collection compoſed by the moſt pregnant and refined Wits of this Age; all which bound up together, I humbly preſent the
Reader with, whoſe kind acceptance will be underſtood by his gratifying liberally the Book ſeller, and giving the unknown Authour a good report, who am yours,

closer.signed: Dum aurâ aethereâ veſcor, W. P.

div.head: MERRY DIALOGUES UPON VARIOUS OCCASIONS: Compoſed of Mirth, Wit, and Eloquence, for a help to Diſcourſe, to ſuch as have had but ſmall Converſe with the Critical Sort of People which live in this Cenſorious Age.
DIALOGUE 1. A loving Diſcourſe betwixt Samuel and Sarah.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: LOve is the cauſe I have ſo often made my addreſſes to you Madam, therefore let me beſeech you not to diſdain my preſent Suit.

sp.speaker: Sarah,
sp.p: You tell me much of Love, but that's a thing I never yet could underſtand.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: The more is my grief, for if you knew it but half ſo well as I do, I am ſure that you would incline your heart to pity my afflictions.

sp.speaker: Sarah,
sp.p: Why then it ſeems it is an affliction to be in Love, I am therefore glad I never yet knew what it was.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p:
Yes Madam, 'tis a ſorrow and a great affliction
to be in Love, and not to be beloved again.

sp.speaker: Sarah,
sp.p: How's that Sir?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Ah Madam, too well I know it, and twil ell it you if you will give me leave.

sp.speaker: Sarah,
sp.p: Pray Sir, let me hear it.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: The ſad example which I now ſhall inſtance is my own ſelf: I love you Madam, and have often told you ſo, but you have ever ſeem'd to ſlight my kind proffers of Love, to my great torment.

sp.speaker: Sarah,
sp.p: I know not what you mean: wherein have I ever ſlighted you, pray tell me Sir.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I will Madam: you know I have at ſeveral times told you that I loved you, and ſo well, as to marry you and make you my Wife.

sp.speaker: Sarah,
sp.p: And call you that love to marry you, and be your Wiſe, pray how do you make that appear to be love?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Yes, that is love to me, and the greateſt love that tongue can e're expreſs, if that you once would ſay, that you loved me well enough to be my Wife.

sp.speaker: Sarah,
sp.p: Why then, I find I do not yet know what love is, for I never could find in my heart to marry you; but pray tell me how you came to love me, and it may be after I hear how you began to love firſt, that I may learn to follow your example.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Madam, I know your pretended iggorance is but to mock your poor diſconſolate Lover, one that adores you above all the World befides; but however, ſince you ſay that you will follow my example, in loving me as I love you, I muſt tell you, Madam, that the firſt time I ever ſaw your face, Cupid at that inſtant of time borrowed Arrows from your bright Eyes, and bending of his Bow, he ſhot me to the heart, that ſtraight I fell in love with you, and ever ſince that I received this wound, my love-ſick pains grew greater and greater, becauſe you would not grant me love again.

sp.speaker: Sarah,
sp.p: Methinks you talk moſt ſtrangely: you tell me of Cupid, pray what is he, and why does he keep a Bow?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Cupid, Madam, is the little god of Love, a Boy he is, whom the Poets relate to be blind; he has a Bow his Mother Venus gave him, and he borrows Arrows from young Ladies Eyes, and when he pleaſes to ſport himſelf, he bends his Bow and ſhoots where he pleaſes, and where ever it hits, that perſon is ſo ſorely wounded, that he can never reſt night nor day, unleſs the Lady from whoſe Eyes the Arrows came, will grant him love again; which is my condition, and if you deny me love I ſhall be of all men moſt miſerable.

sp.speaker: Sarah,
sp.p: But why do you ſpeak to me Sir to cure you now you ſay you are wounded? you muſt apply your ſelf to that Lady from whence the Arrows came, as for my part I am ſure that I have no Arrows in me, nor I would not that there ſhould be any there, for all the world; that were the way to kill me if I had Arrows in my Eyes: but if there be Ladies that have any ſuch things that wound young men, and can alſo cure them, you had beſt to ceaſe your diſcourſe with me and ſeek till you find them out; as for my part (as I told you before) I declare that I keep no Arrows to hurt any one, neither (according to your own words) can I cure any that are ſo wounded.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Ah Madam, though we have hitherto diſcourſed after the Romantick Way and Mode, yet you well enough know my meaning; therefore, not to talk any longer at this diſtance, I muſt (with your pardon) tell you plainly that I love you Madam, and none but you alone; therefore pity my condition.

sp.speaker: Sarah,
sp.p:
Since you have diſcovered your ſelf to be 1 Lover, and for my ſake, and not only now on a ſudden, but a pretty while ſince, if I may believe you;
but young men are ſo falſe, that I know not what to ſay to you.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: You have tryed my conſtancy, for it is ſome years ſince (you know) I firſt offer'd the tenders of my love to you; and though you anſwer'd me ſtill with flat denial, yet you ſee that I had not ſo ſlightly grounded my paſſion, as that your frowns as yet could make me have an ill opinion of your love.

sp.speaker: Sarah,
sp.p: Well, ſince you are reſolved to proceed, and will take no denial, know then that I muſt try you further ſtill; therefore prepare your ſelf to anſwer me.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Speak boldly, Madam, and let your demands be ne're ſo difficult to perform, if they are in mans power to accompliſh, you ſhall be obeyed, and Madam, gladly too, ſhould you command me this very minute to be my own bloody Executioner.

sp.speaker: Sarah,
sp.p: No Sir, I wiſh you long may live and happy, but if you ere intend to be my Bridegroom you muſt—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: What muſt I do, Madam? ſpeak without fear, your will ſhall be my pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Sarah,
sp.p: No, I am aſham'd to tell you, but yet I can't forbear, but I muſt tell you, you muſt—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Dear Madam, ſpeak and bluſh not.

sp.speaker: Sarah,
sp.p: Why this it is, you muſt come now and kiſs me, and by that kiſs ſwear, that within the ſpace of ſix days you will marry me.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Auſpicious Heaven, and all ye Powers above, to you on bended knees I firſt return my thankful Prayers! and next dear Madam, with humble gratitude, I at your feet do proſtrate fall, where ſilence gladly ſhall ſhew I do conſent; for words cannot expreſs my preſent joy.

sp.speaker: Sarah,
sp.p: Riſe, worthy Sir, you have deſerved my love, nor could I longer keep you in deſpair; from hence call me your own.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: My deareſt onely Joy, you have now for ever bleſt me, this kiſs ſhall uſher in a thouſand more; give me your hand Ile wait upon you home.
sp.l: Where ſpeedily without the leaſt delay,
We will appoint our Joyful Wedding day:

div.head: DIALOGUE II. A Diſcourſe betwixt Corydon and Celia.

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: WHy deareſt Celia ſhould you prove ſo cruel to him that loves you more than life or any other thing that bears a name? a world of fighs and groans have fill'd the skyes with the Ecchoes of My Celia, Fair and Cruel Caelia; but no redreſs as yet I have found: then dain my pretty Paramour at length to ſmile upon diſtracted Corydon.

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: What means the Shepherd thus to trouble me, what Cruelties are theſe you ſpeak of, for my part I know not of any unkindneſs that I ever ſhew'd to you? What is't you would have, tell me wherein that Caelia has been offenſive to you, and without doubt a ſpeedy recompence will be made you?

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: Oh would that Corydon could find it ſo as Celia has told him, ſoon my deareſt Celia ſhould know the cauſe of all my Miſeries and Woes: You need not ask me Celia why I call you Cruel, my looks will tell you though my tongue be ſilent.

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p:
Indeed Corydon you do miſtake my skill, for I am no good Phyſiognomiſt, neither did I ever pretend to it; therefore if you would that I be made ſenſible of your grief, you muſt tell it me downright, and then if it lies in my power to give you eaſe, and I deny it, you then will have juſt cauſe to call me cruel and not
before: For no Doctor or Surgeon can tell how to apply any remedy to a Sick Patient, before he knows from whence his diſtemper ſprings.

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: You cannot be ſo ignorant as you pretend you are, I cannot think but that you know my grief; 'tis Love, my Deareſt Celia, 'tis Love.

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: How Coryden, did you ſay Love, or did I miſtake that word; ſpeak it again?

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: Yes ſo I will, my Celia, for 'tis Love and the Love of you alone, that I, that I poor Shepherd langaith after thus.

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: And is it ſo? Do you Love me ſo well Corydon, that it makes you ſick? Poor man why do you Love me ſo much then, cannot you forbear?

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: Yes I can forbear to live but not to love. Death will be a Welcome Gueſt to my diſcontented mind.

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: Oh Corydon, why do you talk of death, the very name of death affrightens me; prithee tell me Corydon, does love and death keep company together?

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: No Celia, Life and Love are companions together, and death aſſociates himſelf with diſdain: Do you not know I love you Celia?

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: Why what if you do love me, what then? I won't kill you. I hope every body loves me, I am ſure my Father and Mother does, and what muſt I kill them too? God forbid.

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: Ah Celia thy pretty innocence does make me ſmile, I had thought thou hadſt been more crafty, and by conſequence more cruel, till now I hear thy anſwers; but tell me Celia doeſt thou love me, my ſweeteſt?

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: Yes indeed do I Corydon, and have done, ever ſince you and I played together in our Church-Yard.

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: That's my good Girle, come and kiſs me Celia.

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: Well, are you ſatisfied now, I hope you will not ſay I am cruel now, will ye Corydon?

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: No, no, my pretty Love; thou art kind to me now; come and let me kiſs thee again.

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: No indeed but you muſt not.

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: Why didſt not thou like the laſt kiſs I gave thee Celia?

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: Yes, I lik'd it well enough Corydon; but my Mother always charged me that I ſhould not ſuffer any man to kiſs me.

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: Did thy Mother never talke of me, Celia?

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: Yes, very often Corydon; and I told her how you talk'd of love to me a great while ago, but I knew not what you meant by it, nor don't yet; but my Mother charged me not to come into your company, nor ſuffer you ſo much as to touch me; and told me that I muſt not hear you when you talk of Love, for I muſt love no body but my Father and Mother.

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: Why ſurely ſhe did not tell thee ſo, did ſhe Celia?

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: Yes indeed ſhe did, Corydon, and a great deal more than that; but I ſhall not name it.

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: Yes prithee do Celia, let me hear what 'twas ſhe ſaid to thee?

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: No, indeed you ſhall not, 'twas ſomething ſhe bid me not to let you do, but what it was I will not name for all the world.

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: No more thou ſhalt not Celia, for I gueſs it already, and that's enough for me.

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: Well if you do, you do, I don't much care; but I vow you make me bluſh.

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: Bluſh not my Celia, for I will not name it; come ſit thee down my Celia upon this green bank, and now we have an opportunity, let us make uſe of it in diſcourſing of matters of Love.

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: I know not what you mean Corydon, but I will ſit down a little while with you, for I cannot ſtay; my Mother charged me not to ſtay too long.

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: Why thy Mother does not know that I am with thee.

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: No indeed I think not, for if ſhe did, it would be a wee day with me; for ſhe cannot abide you, becauſe you talk of Love to me.

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: Well but I hope thou wilt love me ne're theleſs for that, wilt thou Celia? I am ſure I love thee well.

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: No indeed I love you well enough, and methinks better now then ever I did before.

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: I thank thee, Celia, but I have other queſtions to ask thee concerning love.

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: What are they Corydon, prithee be not too tedious, for I cannot tarry too long; you know my Mother will chide me.

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: Thou ſayeſt thou loveſt me Celia, but how well?

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: Why a great deal, is not that enough?

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: Well but do'ſt thou love me well enough to be my Wife and to be married to me?

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: Why how muſt I be married to you Corydon?

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: Why we muſt go to Church together, and the Miniſter after ſome Prayers ſaid joynes our hands together, and then we are Man and Wife: why did'ſt thou never ſee any married yet?

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: No not I, never in all my life; but what muſt we do after marriage Corydon, prithee tell me.

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: Why that very night we muſt go to bed together and lie together ſo long as we live.

sp.speaker: Gelia,
sp.p:
Oh ſtrange, why then I muſt not marry with you, for that was the only thing that my Mother charged me to have a care of; and not to lye with you,
nor any other man in the whole World, and I dare not do it if you would give me ſix pence; No, no, I muſt have a care of that, for I know what I know.

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: Why what doeſt thou mean my Love? when we are married I will get thee brave Boys and Girles of thy own, Child what do'ſt thou think of that?

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: Oh fie, oh fie, now you have named it all that my Mother has forewarned me againſt; how dare you name ſuch words, ſure God wo'nt bleſs you Corydon. My Mother told me that God would not bleſs me if I did but think of ſuch things, much leſs dare to act them.

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: That is to ſay before Marriage Celia you ought not to act ſuch things, but marriage makes it lawful with your own husband, and not onely lawful but honourable it is to be a Mother of Children.

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: Say you ſo, Corydon; but my Mother will never yield to this, I am ſure on't.

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: Well but thy Mother will have nothing to do with thee; after we are married thou art at thy huſbands diſpoſing then, no bodies elſe.

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: Well I'le go home and tell my Mother what you ſay, and ſee whether ſhe will give her conſent that I ſhould do all theſe things with you as you have named or no.

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: No, no, my ſweeteſt Celia, by no means, do not acquaint her with it yet.

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: Becauſe you know that ſhe does not affect me ſo well as I do you, and therefore you and I muſt never marry nor ever meet again, if you tell her of any thing that I have ſaid to you.

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: Why what would you have me do then Corydon?

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: Why do'ſt thou love me well enough to be my Wiſe?

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: Yes truely Corydon, you have almoſt perſwaded me too't, if my Mother was but willing.

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: Why then I'le tell thee, Celia, we will marry firſt, and I'le warrant thee we will pleaſe her well enough afterward.

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: Think you ſo Corydon; Well but muſt I have Boys and Girles too, what will ſhe ſay to that?

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: Why what ſhould ſhe ſay my Dear, ſhe will rejoyce to ſee thee have Children, which when they come to bigneſs will ask her bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: Well, but I ſhall be aſham'd to have Children; I vow I ſhall Corydon.

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: Prithee don't talk ſo childiſhly, my Dear, 'twill be an honour to thee to have children.

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: Well, but how ſhall I do to get to bed to thee, I'le ſwear I ſhall not have the face to go to bed to a man.

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: Well, well, we will do well enough for that, meet me here too morrow morning, Celia, and we will go and be married; till then farewel.

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: Nay but ſtay Corydon, I can afford to ſtay a little while longer now, to talk about having of children and going to bed after we are married.

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: Can'ſt thou indeed, poor Rogue, well I love thy innocence, and too morrow at night, thou ſhalt be ſatisfied in every thing that thou doeſt deſire to know, and with this ſweet kiſs at preſent, I take my leave, not willing to detain thee too long too day, for fear thy Mothers Jealouſie ſhould ariſe, and gueſs the truth of what we have deſign'd, and ſo fruſtrate all our hopes and expectations, by keeping thee a cloſe Priſoner in her houſe, and not ſuffer thee to ſtir abroad any whither, not let me come to ſee thee: therefore deareſt Celia be careful, and ſay not a word to her of what we have been talking of; for if you do, I am ſure our loves for ever will be ruined.

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: I'le warrant thee Corydon ſhe ſhall never know the leaſt through me, I can keep my own Counſel well enough; and that ſhe ſhall find to her anger and vexation.

sp.speaker: Corydon,
sp.p: 'Tis a good Girle, well, fare thee well once again; My Deareſt, Remember what you have to do too morrow.

sp.speaker: Celia,
sp.p: Adieu dear Corydon, farewell my loving Shepherd. Yes ſurely, I ſhall not forget the time and place of meeting, my Eyes no reſt ſhall take this night; my mind will be employed another way: the thoughts of what I have to do too morrow will buſie me enough 'twixt this and then.
sp.l: A Virgin pure I'le to the Temple go,
And there the Marriage Rites of Hymen know.

div.head: DIALOGUE III. A Diſcourſe betwixt two Gentlemen as they were riding on the Road together.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: GOod morrow to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Rowlandus,
sp.p: A good morning to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: How far do you ride in this Road Sir?

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: As far as I can Sir too day.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: That's as much as to ſay as far as your Horſe will carry you too day; for poſſibly you may be capable of riding farther in a day than he is able to perform.

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: You ſay right, Sir, but I love my Horſe too well to wrong him by over-riding him.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: You are the better Maſter Sir.

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: Yes, and by conſequence he the better Horſe Sir.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: All this I muſt confeſs, Sir; but pray now let me know how far you ride, Sir, this way; for I ſhall be more than a little glad of your good company, if you will be pleaſed to accept of mine?

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: Sir, Your company will be an honour to me, therefore you need not make any intreaties, for I ſhall be very forward to conjoyn my ſelf with ſo good ſociety as I ſind you are; and to anſwer your queſtion, I ſhall tell you, Sir, that I intend to reach as far Dunſtable too night, and there to lye, being in my Road to Weſt-Chester, whither I am bound.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: In a happy hour I have ſet forward on my Journey, for I am travelling within ten miles of Cheſter; therefore I hope I ſhall enjoy your company ſo far.

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: With all my heart, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: Your Horſe goes very well Sir, pray what price?

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: My Horſe is a Mare, Sir, and I think ſhe goes well enough, I am ſure ſhe pleaſes me.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: No doubt of it Sir, there is no reaſon why I ſhould miſlike her if ſhe pleaſes you; but how do you like mine Sir?

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: Why Sir, for fear I ſhould make the ſame miſtake as you have done, I muſt tell you that be it Horſe or Mare, or what ever the Beaſt is, I cannot tell but it goes very well.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: It is (to ſpeak after the Jocoſe manner, as you have done) a double hol'd Gelding, a Mare Sir; as we ſay in Engliſh, of the ſame Sex as yours is, but I think not altogether ſo ſtately.

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: Well, we'll make no compariſons Sir, but I believe they both may be very good: but where do you intend to Inn, for this night?

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: Why Sir, I would willingly be directed by you; but I'le tell you where I us'd to lie.

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: Pray, where's that Sir.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: At the Sign of the two Travellers, it is a very good Inn, and there we ſhall have good entertainment for our Horſes and our ſelves; I name the convenience for the Horſe firſt, for if they fare well I don't queſtion but we ſhall do well enough.

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: You ſay true Sir, for they cannot ſpeak for themſelves, but we can, and I'le warrant you we will want for nothing, no more ſhall not the Horſes; 'or I'le take care of that.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: You ſay right Sir, the Mares ſhall want for nothing, for our firſt care ſhall be for them, and then Sir I ſhall be at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: Sir, I am at your ſervice; but pray what a kind of Hoſteſs have we?

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: Nay Sir you ſay right, for we have a very kind Hoſteſs.

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: How do you mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: I mean honeſtly: a very good woman to our Landlady, and ifaith ſhe rules the roaſt.

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: I am glad to hear it Sir, for we intend I hope (at leaſt I do) to have ſome Roaſt, but pray have we never an Hoſt or Landlord there?

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: Yes, yes; we have a Landlord, a very good man, that is to ſay, a very merry Landlord, you ſhall ſee when we come there; but as I tell you, the Hoſteſs his Wife, id eſt, our Landlady, rules the roaſt.

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: And ſo I would have her Sir: for it properly belongs to that ſex to ſee after the Roaſt.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: Well Sir, and ſo I ſay too, but no more of this till we come there.

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: Agreed Sir, but I think we don't want much of it now.

sp.speaker: Tiberius.
sp.p: Sir you ſay true, but ſhall I be honoured ſo far as to be a Supper-man with you as well as a Fellow-traveller?

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: I hope that queſtion is not to ask now, your invitation was ſo fair, that I ſhould be a Churl, and a great one, if I ſhould deny you what ſo readily you have propoſed.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: Why then Sir let's take up our quarters together, but not too faſt, now we are nigh our Inn; but let's ride ſoftly, that our Horſes, alias, Mares, may not be too hot when we come into our Inne.

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: Here Hoſtler.

sp.speaker: Hoſtler,
sp.p: Who calls?

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: Here take our Horſes.

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: And rub them down clean, and come to us by and by, and you ſhall be informed what Corn we intend to give them.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: Will you be pleaſed to walk into the Kitchin, and ſee what's there you like for Supper?

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: Yes Sir, I'le follow you, it ſeems you are acquainted with my Landlady; therefore pray walk firſt and renew your acquaintance with her.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: Your ſervant Sir, I'le obey your commands.
Landlady your humble Servant, how have you done this many a day.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſs.
sp.p: Why let me ſee, who's this Maſter Tiberius?

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: The very ſame.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſs,
sp.p: Lord is there ſuch a man alive?

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: Yes I am alive ſtill Landlady; and this Gentleman and I do intend to be your Gueſts too night.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſs,
sp.p: Come old Boys, I'le give each of you a kiſs if you'l meet me half way, and bid you wellcome: So, now you are wellcome Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: Well, honeſt Landlady, what ſhall we have for Supper?

sp.speaker: Hoſteſs,
sp.p: Troth e'ne what you pleaſe Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: Well but what have you got in the Houſe Landlady?

sp.speaker: Hoſteſs,
sp.p: Why you may have a couple of Capons, or a couple of Pullets, or a dozen of Pidgeons, with two or three dozen of Larks; you know Sir that we live in the onely Lark Country in England: but if you be not pleaſed with hollow birds, you may have a Shoulder of Mutton, Or a Loyn of Veal, or any boil'd Meat, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: Well Landlady you have nam'd varieties enough, come you know my old Cuſtome, give me a pint of your beſt Sack, and whil'ſt we are drinking that, we ſhall have time to conſider which of theſe diſhes of Meat to pitch upon.

sp.speaker: Hosteſs,
sp.p: You ſhall have it Sir.

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: We have a good Jovial Landlady here I perceive Sir?

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: Yes Sir, ſhe will talke merrily, but I really believe it is onely to pleaſe her gueſts; for I am very confident that ſhe is honeſt.

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: No doubt of it Sir, for you know we commonly find that the greateſt talkers are the leaſt doers.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſs,
sp.p: Gentlemen I'le make bold to begin, and preſent my ſervice to you both, and you are both wellcome.

sp.speaker: Both,
sp.p: Thank you Landlady.

sp.speaker: Hosteſs,
sp.p: Mr. Tiberius I'le preſent it to you firſt, becauſe you are my old acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: Thank you Landlady.
Sir my humble ſervice to you, and I thank you for your good company.

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: Your ſervant Sir, I am glad of ſo good a companion as your ſelf; come Landlaiy the t'other glaſs to you, and then wee'l think what to have for Supper.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſs,
sp.p: With all my heart Sir: But Mr. Tiberius, where have you been this many a day?

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: Why about the World Landlady, ſometimes in one place, and ſometimes in another. You ſee I am alive ſtill.

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: Well Sir, now what ſhall we have for Supper?

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: Pray Sir do you ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: Why I think a ſhoulder of Mutton, and two or three dozen of my Landladies Larks, ſince ſhe praiſes them ſo much.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: Agreed, withal my Heart.
Landlady, pray take care that they be made ready preſently.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſs,
sp.p: They ſhall Sir, will you be pleaſed to walk up into your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: Yes Landlady, we will walk up; but though we ſup together, yet we muſt have two Chambers to lie in.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſs,
sp.p: You ſhall Sir. What will you be pleaſed to drink Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: VVhy let's taſte of your Ale and Beer, Landlady, will you?

sp.speaker: Hoſteſs,
sp.p: Yes you ſhall Sir. —Exit Hosteſs.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: VVell, but pray Fellow traveller, give me your abſolute Opinion of our Landlady?

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: VVhy Sir, as I told you before, ſhe may be honeſt; for what I know by her, I am ſure ſhe is; but for your own part I believe that you know ſomething by her, by your redoubling the queſtion of what I thought of her; beſides that is not all the ground I have for ſuſpicion, for I have obſerv'd ſome amorous wanton glances caſt towards you now and then, when we were in the Kitchin, and alſo ſince we came up into the Chamber: but what the meaning of it ſhould be is beſt known to your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: Fie Sir, Fie, ſure you miſtake your ſelf; ſhe did not look and ſmile on me, did ſhe?

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: Nay I am ſure I am not miſtaken, for ſhe did ſmile and caſt a wanton eye on you too.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: VVell well Sir, how do you like her, did ſhe not kiſs well?

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: In troth Sir I cannot tell, I took ſo little notice of it, 'twas onely for faſhions ſake, that I kiſs'd her; not out of any deſire I had to it, but to fulfil the ancient cuſtom.

sp.speaker: Hoſtler,
sp.p: VVhat corn will you be pleaſed to give your Horſes, Sirs?

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: VVhy give mine half a peck of Oats too night, and the like quantity in the morning.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: And let mine have the ſame.

sp.speaker: Hoſtler,
sp.p: They ſhall Sir.

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: Here Hoſtler, take the pot and drink.

sp.speaker: Hoſtler,
sp.p: Thank you Maſter.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: Be ſure let them have their due.

sp.speaker: Hoſtler,
sp.p: I'le warrant you Sir.

sp.speaker: Hostleſs,
sp.p: Gentlemen your Supper is ready, will you have it brought up yet?

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: Yes, Yes, by all means Landlady, bring it up; for we think long till we be at it: I am ſure I do.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſs,
sp.p: You ſhall have it immediately Sir; will you be pleaſed to ſeat your ſelves?
So here 'tis come now.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: Come Landlady ſit you down pray, where's my Landlord your Husband?

sp.speaker: Hoſteſs,
sp.p: Alas poor Cuckold, where ſhould he be, he is abroad about his buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: How's that Landlady, you do but jeſt ſure?

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: No, no, ſhe uſes to talk after this rate, I know; but I believe my Landlord is no Cuckold for all that.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſs,
sp.p: Well, come Gentlemen fall too, I have ſaid grace for you.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: VVell ſaid Landlady, I perceive you are merry; but we will every one ſay grace for himſelf.

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: So, Now Landlady be pleaſed to help your ſelf, and we will cut afterwards.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: VVell Landlady, I know your temper; you connot eat well without a bottle or two of Claret.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſs.
sp.p: VVell, then if you know my humour, I hope you will let me have it; for I ſhall live the longer, and I know you would not have me die yet, for you'l never meet with ſuch another Landlady.

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: Yes, yes, Landlady, if that a bottle or two of VVine will prolong your days, you ſhall have that Cordial to be ſure; and I am alſo in your opinion, that a good Supper cannot be made without a bottle or two of VVine.
Here Boy bring us up a bottle of Claret.

sp.speaker: Boy,
sp.p: By and by, you ſhall have it Sir.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: Come Landlady, have we never a merry Jeſt at Supper?

sp.speaker: Hoſteſs,
sp.p: Are you married Sir?

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: Yes, that I am Landlady.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſs,
sp.p: VVhy, then you are a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: How do you know that Landlady?

sp.speaker: Hoſteſs,
sp.p: VVhy, it follows by confequence, that all men that are married, muſt of neceſſity be Cuckolds, becauſe my Husband's one.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: Suppoſe your Husband be one, muſt all men therefore be Cuckolds, becauſe he is ſo? ſurely all the VVomen in the VVorld are not VVhores.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſs,
sp.p: Oh Fie, Mr. Tiberius, I had thought you could not have ſpoke ſuch a word, I vow I could find in my heart to be angry with you; what muſt all thoſe women that make their husbands Cuckolds, be called Whores, no ſure I hope not?

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: Nay, but Landlady, ſetting all aſide, how do you call thoſe VVomen as make their Husbands Cuckalds? if they are not VVhores, I am much miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſs,
sp.p: Lord Sir, I had thought that you had lived long enough in the World to know better things: Suppoſe I or ſome other VVoman, ſhould be willing to ſatisfie your deſires, in that way, rather then diſoblige you, methinks you would not call me or the or whoever it be, VVhore, for condeſcending to your will.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: VVhy, what would you have her accounted then Landlady?

sp.speaker: Hoſteſs,
sp.p: You may ſay ſhe is a kind VVoman, or ſo: a good natur'd VVoman, or ſo: but the name of whore is ſo odious, that it deſerves not to be given for it, except the party ſo called be a common ſtrumpet and mercenary, proſtrating her ſelf to any ſort of fellow, for half a Crown or under; ſhe indeed deſerves the Name of VVhore, and no other VVoman whatſoever.

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: VVell Landlady, it ſhall be as you ſay; come one glaſs of Claret to you, and all ſhall be well I hope.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſs,
sp.p: Sir, I'le pledge, and now I hope you underſtand the difference betwixt a VVhore and a kind VVoman.

sp.speaker: Tiberius,
sp.p: VVell well, Landlady, we are ſatisfied, and too morrow morning before we go, you ſhall be ſatiſfied too.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſs,
sp.p: I queſtion it not, Gentlemen, good night Sir; Mr. Tiberius, if you pleaſe, you ſhall lie in another chamber, and this Gentleman ſhall lie here.

sp.speaker: Rowland,
sp.p: VVith all my heart Landlady. Sir good night to you; pray uſe my Landlady kindly.

div.head: DIALOGUE IIII. A Merry diſcourſe betwixt Harry and Doll, in Country Phraiſes.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: HOneſt Doll, well met in troth, whither art thou going, this morning ſo early?

p.hi: Why, what is that to you, Good man Coxcomb, I hope I am not to make you acquainted with my Maſter and Dames beſineſs; that would be a pretty Jeſt indeed, if I ſhould do ſo; but I think the fool has more wit in truth: pray do you mind your buſineſs, and I will take care of what I have to do, and ſo farewell.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Nay ſtay a little ſweet Dorothy, ſtay, do not be ſo angry, that's my good Girle, what haſt thou piſs'd on a Nettle this morning, that thou art ſo tachy? come, come, Doll, prithee be gentle (for I vow to God) I ask thee for no harm.

p.hi: No harm, ſauce-box, what is't you aske me for then?

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Nay, ſweet Dorothy be patient, and I'le tell thee.

p.hi: Well, come let me hear it.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Why, it was not to enquire after any of thy Maſter or Dames buſineſs, that I ſtoped thee, but becauſe I have a little buſineſs of my own to tell thee of, if thou wilt hear me with patience.

p.hi: I wonder what I have to do with your buſineſs, I'le bear none of your buſineſs, by the Maſs not I, therefore pray let me go.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Nay, ſtay a little Doll, you muſt hear me, I'le ſwear I ſhall cry if you are thus unkind to me, therefore prithee ſtay and hear me.

p.hi: How do you ſay, ſhall you cry?

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Yes that I ſhall, and die too, if you be not more kinder to me.

p.hi: Well, come fool, rather than you ſhall cry, and die too, I will ſtay and hear what 'tis you have to ſay to me, if that you'll promiſe me not to be too long about it.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: No indeed Doll, I will not keep thee too long, I will be as brief as may be.

p.hi: Come then begin, why don't you begin, I ſay?

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Nay, but heark ye Doll, I do not take this to be a very convenient place, being in a common Footpath, and in the open Field.

p.hi: Why, whither now I trow?

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Why, I'le tell thee Doll, on t'other ſide of yonder Field you know is a little River, and by the River ſide is a moſt pleaſant Grove, where we may fit and talk of our buſineſs, and no body never ſee us, nor diſturb us.

p.hi: You tell me of buſineſs and buſineſs, but I know not what your buſineſs is.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Come along dear Dolly, come along, and I will tell thee preſently, to thy ſatisfaction and content.

p.hi: Well, I could find in my heart to go along with you, but it muſt be upon theſe conditions.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: What conditions, what doſt thou mean ſweetheart?

p.hi: Hey day, pray how came I to be your ſweet-heart? to my beſt knowledge I never ſaw you but once before, and then I am ſure you never talk'd of Love to me.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Tis no matter for that dear Dolly, the more's to come; but prithee, firſt let me hear what the conditions muſt be that I am to ſubſcribe to, for indeed Doll, I begin to be a little in haſt.

p.hi: Pray stay, I am not ſo haſty, however 〈…〉 you my Conditions.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Pray, ſweet Dolly, let me hear 'em then quickly.

p.hi: Yes, you ſhall; and theſe they are.
Firſt, you ſhall ſwear, that you won't tell my Master nor Dame, nor none of my fellow Servants, nor any body elſe that knows me.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: What, muſt I not tell them Doll?

p.hi: Why, I ſay you ſhall not tell any of them that I go to talk with you privately; and then ſecondly;

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Oh dear, ſecondly, why what's next Doll; the firſt I'le ſwear too willingly, but is there any more?

p.hi: Yes, Yes; ſecondly I ſay, you ſhall not offer any rudeneſs to me, when we are alone, you ſhall not—

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: What, doſt thou mean Doll? thou know'ſt I am not rude but gentle; but prithee what do'ſt thou call rudeneſs?

p.hi: Nay, if you interrupt me thus, we ſhall never have done, I ſay,—

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: What, what, dear Dolly, what doſt thou ſay, ſpeak out VVench?

p.hi: But you will not give me leave to ſpeak, I think; why, I ſay, you ſhall not offer any uncivility to me.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: VVhat's that Dolly, that's a hard word, I'le proteſt it is a very hard word.

p.hi: That is to ſay, you ſhall not offer to do any thing to me but kiſs me when we come there, and that not above twice or thrice.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Oh law Doll, thou talk'ſt ſtrangely, why what would'ſt thou have me do more, I intend to do nothing elſe, onely to kiſs and talk of buſineſs.

p.hi: Come, come, for all you pretend ſo much ignorance, I dare not trust you, unleſs you ſwear.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: What wouldſt thou have me ſwear to Dolly?

p.hi:
Why, If I must tell you plainly, I muſt; You ſhall
ſwear that you will not put your hands under my Coats.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Why, what ſhould I put them there for Doll, hey?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis no matter for that; will you ſwear, will you ſwear Harry?

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Yes, I can ſwear Doll.

p.hi: Ay, ay, I don't queſtion that, but will you?

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Yes, I will ſwear Doll, but what muſt the Oath be?

p.hi: Why, the Oath ſhall be this, you ſhall ſwear by your—

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: By my what Doll?

p.hi: Why, you ſhall ſwear, by your honeſty, and by your Maiden-head, that you will not abuſe me.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: How can I abuſe one that I love ſo well: No, no, that cannot be.

p.hi: Well, but however you ſhall ſwear as I have told you.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Yes, yes, I will ſwear boldly Dolly, by my everlaſting honeſty; but what's the t'other word that I muſt ſwear by Doll?

p.hi: Why, by your Maiden-head, I told you.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Prithee what's that Doll?

p.hi: Nay, if you know not, I ſhall not tell you.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Why, then I'le ſwear on at a venture?

p.hi: Do ſo then if you will.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: VVhy, then by my pure honeſty, and by my Maiden-head, which I know not of, I will not Miſuſe thee.

p.hi: Well, come then, I don't much care if I go along with you.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Come on ſweet Dolly, prithee give me thy fiſt, and we will walk lovingly together.

l.hi: Then away they did walk,
To the fine ſhady Grove,
Where no body could them eſpy.

lg.l: There Harry did tell her

l.hi: The pleaſures of love,
And I'le tell them to you by and by.
Though he was a Clown,
Yet he well underſtood
That Women de love to Embrace.

lg.l: He gave Doll a green gown,

l.hi: In the midst of the Wood,
'Twas a pretty convenient place.
But liſten a while,
And you'l bear their diſcourſe,

lg.l: How Harry proceeds in his wooing,
He made Doll to ſmile.

l.hi: Who seeded no force,

lg.l: Though Harry begun to be doing.

p.hi: Well, now we are come to the place, I ſuppoſe, which you told me of?

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Yes, ſo we are Dolly, and now in this pretty ſhady place, under this tree, we will ſit down and diſcourſe about the buſineſs.

p.hi: Yes, prithee do, lets hear this buſineſs, that has been ſo long a bringing out.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: VVhy, then this it is Dolly, I muſt tell you that I love you, and not a little, but a great deal Dolly, I vow I do.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Well, and what then Harry?

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Why, then let's kiſs a little, nay, again and again too.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p:
Nay, but hold Harry, you remember your Oath you ſwore, before I conſented to come hicher with you;
which was, that you ſhould he civil and not kiſs me above once or twice, or three times at fartheſt.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: I'll ſwear Dolly, I had almoſt forgot that, but if I have exceeded a little beyond my bounds, you won't be angry I hope, will you Doll?

p.hi: Nay, I don't know what you mean, methinks you tempt me ſtrangely.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: I'll warrant Girle I'll do thee no harm, don't fear it; come, t'other kiſs and then —

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: And what then Harry? Well but you ſaid you loved me, but how much, or how little, or for what, I cannot yet till.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Oh, oh, I'll tell thee that preſently.

p.hi: Nay, but I must know juſt now?

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Why, I love thee abundantly Dolly, even ſo much that I could find in my heart to —

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: To do what Harry?

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Why, to kiſs thee again, and to hug thee lovingly.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Is that all? but don't you intend to marry me too Harry.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Marry thee▪ Yes, yes child, I'll marry thee by and by, even juſt now.

p.hi: Yes, I do ſo, therefore let me have no excuſes, but make me your wife forthwith.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Then it ſeems you are in as much haſt now as I was before? Well, ſatisfie thy ſelf Doll, for I will make thee my wife, and will prove an honeſt careful husband to thee, what can'ſt thou deſire more?

p.hi: Nay, if you prove as good as your word, I ſhall not need to defire any more; but when will you appoint the time, that I may make ſome ſmall preparation?

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: I leave that to thee Doll: but be private in it and conceal what is paſt, for people you know will make the worſt of any thing they hear.

p.hi: As for my ſecreſie, you need not doubt it, for the making of this our meeting known, would reflect upon me as much as an your ſelf, and rather more.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Thou ſayeſt true Dol; therefore prithee let's make an end at preſent, and do thou name the day when we ſhall meet again, and I will Marry thee without delay, hoping that thou wilt prove an honeſt, kind, and vertuous Wiſe to me.

p.hi: I will ſo, and for ever be obedient to thy Commands; and ſince you leave it to me to appoint the time, I think juſt this day week, at the ſame hour we met too day, will be a very good time if you think it ſo.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: I do agree to it, and I will be ſure to meet thee that morning in this ſame place where now we are, and from hence we will go to the Church and be married privately, and then return to our ſervices again, where we will ſtay till our years are up, and then I eare not if all the world do know that we are Man and Wife.

p.hi: A match my deareſt Love, this kiſs ſhall part our bodies for this time; yet ſurely know, that though I am gone, thou beareſt away my heart; my body to my heart ſhall ſhortly go.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.l: Sweet Dolly fare thee well till next we meet,
Ten thouſand kiſſes, kiſſes that are ſweet
I'le give thee here at parting; do but gueſs
The number till I make them numberleſs.
Rejoyce my Dolly, for our Wedding day
Will quickly come, Love's time makes no delay.
Prepare thy ſelf, and every thing provide
Againſt that day to meet me, not with pride,
But bleſt humility, and loving Charms,
Such as become a faithful Bridegrooms Arms:
Fear nothing Dolly, for I will requite
All theſe paſt favours on our Wedding night.

div.head: DIALOGUE V. A merry Diſcourſe betwixt two Poets, meeting with one another accidentally in the Street.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: BRother Tom, well met; how goes the affairs of the world now a-days?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: In troth Will very dull, mighty dull; I'le ſwear, methinks, all the world is dull but we; and Faith we ſhall be dull too, except we can get more money; I ſpeak for my own part, I know not how your Pockets ſtand affected, I am ſure mine find a mighty Vacuum of late.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Prithee now don't ſay ſo, I know you cannot want money except you are covetous, and ſo want by conſequence, according to that old Adage, which tells us, that ſemper avarus eget.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Prithee Will don't ſpeak Latine, for I cannot underſtand a word ſo long as Aegrotat Crumena; beſides, I have drank never a drop of Sack, nor no other Wine; therefore how canſt thou expect that I can ſpeak or underſtand a word of Latine.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Come, come, Brother Tom, we live by our Wits, we muſt not want money, for my part I have money enough; Come, come along with me, I'le revive thy ſpirits with ſome of the Heliconian Liquor, and you know Faecundi Calices Tom will inſpire our Brains, and make our Muſes fing ſuch delightful ſtrains, that ſhall charm the Uſurers Gold to fly into our Pockets, and ne're repine for being bountiful.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
On my word Will. you are very bri • k, but what Tavern ſhall we go to; methinks I cannot turn my head on neither ſide, but my Noſe ſmells Sack ever
ſince you talkt of going to the Tavern, for I'le ſwear I have a very empty Cavern; therefore prithee Will. name the place quickly, and we will diſcourſe of all • hings there as we ſhall think fit.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Prithee Tom go whither thou wilt, for my part it is all one to me; but I think we had as good go to the Devil, becauſe we are juſt by it.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: No Will, I don't care for going to the Devil now, for there I ſhall meet with a ſmall Dun; it is no great matter, I owe five or ſix Pounds, or thereabouts.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Well then avoid Satan, we'll come not near thee; but name ſome other place Tom.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Why, there is a glaſs of as good Wine at the Roſe, and there whatſoever we ſay ſhall be under the Roſe; and that's as nigh as the other: beſides the head Drawer is my very good friend, he never lets me pay a Farthing for Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Prithee don't talk of ſuch pittiful things as paying for Tobacco; if he will draw us a Bottle of good Wine, that ſhall be all we expect from him. Tom, we muſt keep ſuch fellows as Drawers are at a diſtance, leſt they grow ſaucy.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: But I am forced to make them my Familiars, ſometimes againſt my will, but it's no matter for that, come let's go.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Come along Tom, I'll lead the way.
A Drawer comes to them at the Roſe.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: You are welcome Gentlemen, will you be pleas'd to walk up ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yes, honeſt Drawer, we will follow you up ſtairs as faſt as we can.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: What Wine will you be pleas'd to drink Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Heark you, be you the Head-Drawer?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yes, yes, this honeſt Drawer knows me well enough.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Well honeſt Drawer, ſince he calls thee ſo, prithee bring us up a Bottle of the beſt Canary in the Cellar; be ſure let it be good, and thou ſhalt loſe nothing for thy civility.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Your Servant. Sir, I'll warrant you rare good, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Do you hear, bring up ſome Tubacco with you alſo, ſuch as I us'd to ſmoke when I come here.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: You ſhall have it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: We ſhall want a third man to help hold a diſcourſe, ſhall we not? What do you think of a third man, Will. I know where to ſend for one?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: A Por of a third man; tell me of no third man: I'll warrant thee, that we'll find Diſcourſe enough betwixt our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Here's a Glaſs of rich Canary, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Give it me: Will. give me thy hand: Come, a good Health to the Muſes our Siſters, our old Sire Apollo.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Well bowl'd Boy. Come, give me a Rummer, I'll pledge thee.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Does the Wine pleaſe you, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Thou art an honeſt Lad, 'tis very good Wine, and I'll remember thy Box for it.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Come Tom, fill the other Glaſs and drink to me, I'll warrant thee this will put thee out of thy dull humour: Come be merry old Soul, Let's quaff whilſt we may: None knows who ſhall live to be merry next day.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Nay, if thou begin'ſt to be inſpir'd already, what ſhall we be before we go: Come Will. God bleſs the King.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Prithee Tom drink off thy Glaſs: What thou doſt not begin to ſtart already? Come ſuck him off, and I'll pledge thee a brimmer.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: So now I hope I have pleas'd you, Will.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Yes, ſo thou haſt Tom. and I'll do the like, I'll warrant Boy.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I think we had beſt to call for the other Bottle before we begin to ſmoke.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Do ſo Tom, do you call, becauſe you know the Drawer.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Well, I'll knock. Here Drawer, B • y.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: By and by, I am coming Sir.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Prithee draw us a Bottle of the ſame Wine.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: You ſhall have it Sir.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Come Tom, now let's ſmoke it awhile.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Agreed: But ſtay, let's do nothing raſhly, let's rake each of us another Glaſs firſt. Is this the ſame Wine, Drawer?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: The very ſame Sir.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Come Will, here's my Miſtreſſes health.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Drink it off Tom, and pledge mine, and then —

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Ay, and then, as thou ſayeſt Will. we ſhall be fit for diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: So, now let it reſt awhile, and prithee tell me how thou haſt ſpent thy time of late: Upon what new Subject haſt thou exercis'd thy fancy of late.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
Why, I'll tell thee Will, but t'other day there comes to my Lodging a brisk and lively Blade, a good Sack-drinker, but a younger Brother, and he like other men now adays (I won't ſay thee, and I VVill. becauſe he was no Poet) had more Wit than Money. This Young Gentleman had found out a Female Creature that had more Money than Wit, whom he thought were a very fit Match for him: He told me, that he had often made his Addreſſes to her, ſhe not giving him a flat denial, he was perſwaded, that his own Wit, with the aſſiſtance of a ſmooth Poem in praiſe of her Perfections (or Imperfections, all's one in that Greek you know Will.) might win her, and work upon her
fooliſh good Nature, ſo far as to accept his ſuit.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: And how then Tom?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Nay, I muſt drink the other Glaſs before I can proceed any further with my Story.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Well, drink and be hang'd, you love this Sack, I perceive.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Faith Will. 'twas well ſaid: Let me drink before I am hang'd, for I love Sack better than hanging by far.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Well, but go on with the Story.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Then I told him Will, that I could fit him to a hair with a Copy of Verſes, but I exprcted to have ſomething in hand, and a promiſe what I ſhould have after I had done. The young Fop heightred with the thoughts of good ſucceſs, gave me a Guinny in hand, being all the Money he had, I ſuppoſe; and a promiſe of four more if he married the young Gentlewoman: which I gladly took, and could not in Conſcience but give him a glaſs of Wine out of it.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Well, and you did give him Sack out of his Guinny, did you not Tom?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Why yes, I tell thee, I did make him drink for his Money; we had two Bottles of Clarer, and that look'd more gentile than one Bottle of Sack, though I muſt confeſs, that I love Sack far better than French-Wine, Will, and ſo here's to thee.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Nay I believe that you love Sack well enough, without ſwearing to't; for you ſignifie as much by your preſent drinking. Well, now you have took off your Glaſs, I hope you will proceed with your Narration concerning the Poems you were to make.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yes, I will ſo; but had not we beſt to drink another Glaſs apiece firſt: I vow this is excellent good Sack, Will.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Yes, yes, the Sack's good enough; but prithee be not ſo greedy of it Tom, but go on with thy Story.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: VVell here's one Glaſs to thee VVill, and then —

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: And then I think thou'lt be drunk, Tom, come prithee make haſte then, for I am impatient of thy tediouſneſs.

sp.speaker: Tom,
sp.p: Well, if thou wilt not pledge me Will, I'll ſet it by a while, and proceed with my young Gameſter, which was after this manner. I bad him come again that day week he gave me the Guinny, and he ſhould have the Poems.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Why, thou waſt not a week ſure in compoſing a Copy of Verſes in praiſe of a Ladies Beauty?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: No indeed, I was not Will; I wonder how thou hapeneſt to ask ſuch an impertinent Queſtion?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: How do you make it an impertinent Queſtion? did you not ſay, that you bid the Gentleman come that day week, and he ſhould have his Poem?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yes, I did ſay ſo, and do ſay ſo ſtill, and ſay the truth too, Mr. Will, and yet that is no good ground for you to ſay that I was a week in making them; I'll ſwear if you were not my Brother Poet, I would call thee Fool. Why, doſt thou not know that I had a Guinny?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Yes, I do remember you told me ſo, but what then?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: What then, why art thou ignorant ſtill? Doſt thou think that the Guinny would not require ſome time in ſpending?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: 'Tis right Tom, I blame my preſent dulneſs of apprehenſion in not underſtanding thee at firſt; I muſt confeſs that I might have imagined that thou couldſt not reſt, or ſettled thy ſelf to any thing till the Guinny was conſumed and melted away.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
Yes, as thou ſayeſt Will, I did melt it in a ſhore time, but not all at one time; for I would ſtudy and compoſe three or four Lines, then to the Tavern for
half a pint of the beſt Canary, and having drunk up that, I could make a ſhift to go home and compoſe two Verſes and a half more, and then to the Tavern again. But now I think on't, this Wine that ſtands by me, will be flat if it ſtands any longer, therefore Will, here's to thee.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: What again? why ſure enough I ſhall be troubled to get thee home by and by.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yes, it may be ſo. Here Drawer, Boy.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: By and by, Sir, I am coming. Did you call here, Sir?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yes; Prithee bring us a Bottle of the ſame Wine, and bring a Chamber-pot with thee.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: You ſhall have it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: We ſhall have the other Bottle, ſhall we not Will?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Yes, it ſeems we muſt have it; now you have call'd for't.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: There are Muſicians below, Gentle men, who deſire to know whether you will permit them to play to you or no?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Hang 'em Rogues, we have rothing to do with Fidlers, our Sack will make us more merry than their ſcraping.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Thou ſayeſt right Will, and now I love thee, and here's • o thee.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Come drink Tom, and let me hear what Verſes thou madeſt the young man for his Guinny, I know thou haſt a foul Copy of them about thee ſtill, haſt not, Tom.?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Why, what if I have or have not, muſt I needs tell you Will; or is there any neceſſity that I ſhould ſhew them to you, if I have 'em about me?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: No, no, Tom, I do not Command you to ſhew me, but I deſire that kindneſs of you; therefore don't be angry.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: No, no, Will, angry, I ſcorn to be angry; Come here's to thee.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Well, but will you ſhew me the Poem that you made for the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: No, in troth won't I, but I'll read it to you, if that will fatisfie you, if not, you muſt defiſt to ask me further, for I will not part from them out of my own hands to ne're a man in England; yet I muſt confeſs, that I love you well Will, but you muſt pardon me for that.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Why are they ſuch excellent ones that you are afraid that I ſhould take them away, and ſo make uſe of them, ſome other time upon the ſame occaſion?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter for that, if you will hear them you ſhall Will.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Well, prithee, let's hear 'em then.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Why, you ſhall; but here's to you firſt, I begin to be dry.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Well, prithee drink, and read 'em if thou wilt, or ſay thou wilt not.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yes, I will, and theſe they are, pray give attention:

l.hi: Madam, your Beauty, hang me, like an Elf,
I need not praiſe, for that will praiſe it ſelf:
I cannot flatter you, yet muſt confeſs,
That I could love you well, if you had leſs.
For what I love you for, I know you gueſs.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: How's that? How's that?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Nay, if you interrupt me, I ha' done.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Proceed.

l.hi: I love you, Madam, more than Pig or Pye,
And if you love me not, I'll ſit and cry,
And curſe my cruel fate and deſtiny,
until I waſte, and pine away, and dy;
And if my Mother ask the reaſon why,
Then Madam, you muſt bear the ſhame, not I,
Becauſe you work my woe by cruelty;
But if you are kind and grant my ſuit, I'le fly
Into your arms with joy, and there I'le lye,
And kiſs and hugg to perpetuity,
And nothing want that's underneath the Sky;
Then be not coy, nor ſoftly ſay, fie, fie;
If that I lie, as cloſe as Pig in Stie.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Oh, wonderful, wonderful Wit! I never heard the like in all my life; ſo many Rhimes of one ſort I never heard in my life time.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: That's the rarity of it, Will.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Yes, ſo I perceive Tom. What did you conclude you Elegant Poem after this manner?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: No, there is two Lines more, and that is all; which are theſe:

l.hi: Thus Miſtreſs, hoping you'll not count me rude,
Until anon I ſee you, I conclude.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Oh, admirable Tom! I could not have thought that any man alive had had ſo much wit in him; Well, go thy way for a Compoſer of Poems: ſo excellent a Fancy, I never heard before.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: No nor no body elſe, except it came from thoſe that are good Sack Drinkers like my ſelf: Come here's to thee Will, let's drink a little touch now.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I'll pledge thee Tom, a brimmer: Drawer, bring the t'other Bottle, and tell us what's to pay?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: You ſhall have it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Come Will, prithee tell me what new thing thou haſt made of late, ſpeak Will, and briskly, to be dull I hate.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: This Sack has witty Charms I do perceive,
It fools inſpires, I aptly do believe.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Then give us Sack, give us Sack,
'Tis pity, we ſhould ever lack.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Drink ſtoutly Tom, thou ſhalt not want,
I find it helps the ignorant.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Come, Drawer, quick, and bring ſome ſmoke;
To drink more Wine it will provoke.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I value not the Indian Funk,
It rather cauſes to be drunk.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Fie Will, none can be drunk but Sots,
That in an Ale-houſe tope black Pots:
Wine only does transform our Souls;
A Block-head's witty with full Bowls.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I'm apt to think, thou tell'ſt me true,
Then prithee Tom, take thou thy due:
Thy Guinny Poem wanted Wine,
Thy muddy Brains for to refine:
Let's ceaſe to Rhime ex tempore,
We'll drink and laugh and merry be.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Thou ſayeſt true Will, we had better leave off Rhiming in vain, for why ſhould we waſte our ſtock of Wit upon each other when we have no occaſion for it; we have enough to ſtudy our Brains when we have a Gninny Subject to work upon. In troth Will, I begin to be troubled with a ſhort Cough, I don't know what they call it; Prithee give me another Claſs of Sack, and try what that will do with me.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Ay, ay, the t'other Glafs, prithee drink it off, and begin an other to me, that we may make an end, for it begins to be late.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Thou ſayeſt true Will, and here's to thee.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: So now, we'll call for a Reckoning. Here Drawer, What's to pay?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Eight ſhillings Wine, and ſix pence Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Here's nine ſhillings, take thou the remainder.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir, you are welcome Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Well fare thee well Will, the next Treat ſhall be mine.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Adien honeſt Tom, let me ſee thee ſometimes. Fare-well.

div.head: DIALOGUE VI. A merry Dialogue of Love betwixt an Old Rich Guff and a handſome br •• k Damſel.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: MY Cocky, My pretty Nancy Cock, how doſt thou my Sweeting? in troth Law; I am glad to ſee thee with all my heart. Come, how haſt thou done this great while? what, art thou marri'd yet my Girl? haſt got thee a good Husband yet?

p.hi: Your Servant Sir, I hope your Worſhip's in good health.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: Yes, in good truth Girl, I thank my God, I am in good health, and am as lively and luſty, as e're I was in all my life: But prithee tell me Nancy, art a Wife or a Maid? Tell me truly, don't bluſh.

p.hi: I am a Maid, an't pleaſe you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: In goed time, my Sweeting: But I wonder thou haſt not got thee a Husband all this while.

p.hi: I hope he is got already, Sir.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: Well, well, pretty one, you know my meaning: I tell thee; I wonder ſuch a pretty ſweet-fac'd Rogue has not a Husband yet.

p.hi: Becauſe I can get no Body to have me, Sir; however I think it is time enough yet, for I am young in years, and may be brought too ſoon to know the ſorrows of a wedded life.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: Be not miſtaken Sweeteſt; there are no pleaſures in the world like to thoſe which married people receive when they are joyn'd together by free conſent, and where there is no want of an Eſtate to keep Love warm; for I muſt confeſs that Poverty often makes Love grow cold, and want of Neceſſaries makes Quarrels ariſe; But where there is a ſufficiency and plenty of all things, together with a loving and kind Husband, I think that woman is in a happy condition: What thinks't thou of this my Nancy, come anſwer me now Girl?

p.hi: Why truly Sir, ſuch Husbands are hard to be found; but if I knew where to have ſuch a man, I ſhould be willing enough to alter my condition; for I must confeſs that I have had a longing mind this half year to be a married wife; for ſomething, but I know not yet for what, I had ſo ſtrong a deſire.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: Alas, poor Rogue! pretty innocent Girl, The truth on't is, I do believe that thou art a pure Virgin, and by'r Lady, my Cocky, I will give thee one Salute.

p.hi: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: Nay, my Cocky, be not aſhamed; Nay, prithee don't bluſh.

p.hi: Pray Sir, what do you mean? I hope you will not degrade your ſelf ſo much as to kiſs ſuch a one as I: Pray Sir, forbear.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: I feck Huffy, thou art a ſweet-lip't Rogue, and let me tell thee, that I muſt do more than kiſs thee.

p.hi: I hope you are not in earneſt; you will not as me any harm, will you Sir?

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: Hurt thee? No my Chuck, I do not intend to hurt thee; I love that ſweet face of thine too well to hurt it.

p.hi:
Nay then I care not Sir what you do to me, ſo
you don't hurt me; pray tell me then what you mean to do?

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: Why, I intend to love thee.

p.hi: To love me! and what then Sir?

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.p: To kiſs thee, and hag thee, and to lie with thee all night.

p.hi: Marry God forbid that I ſhould lie with a man; in deed Sir, I dare not do ſuch a thing for all the World; for my Mother has often told me, that I muſt not lie with a man, except I had a Husband.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, my pretty thing, no more; thou ſhalt not he with any man but thy Husband.

p.hi: Why Sir, you are not my Husband, and yet you talk of lying with me.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: Well ſaid, ſweet Face: But what do'ſt think of being my wife? couldſt thou find in thy heart to love me, and prove a vertuous, true, and kind wife to me all days of thy life: Now Cocky ſpeak, for in troth Law, I am in earneſt, and do love thee above all other Maids in the whole world.

p.hi: Do you ſo Sir: But you are old, are you not Sir, pray tell me?

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: Why, what if I am, Child.

p.hi: Why then you'll die before me, Sir, and I ſhall love you ſo well when I am married to you, that it will break my heart, if you ſhould die before me.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: Pretty heart, ſay'ſt thou ſo: Is that all thou doſt object againſt me?

p.hi: Is not that enough Sir, what would you have me ſay more?

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: I muſt confeſs, dear Heart, that I am older than thee; but you muſt know, Cocky, that we all muſt die, both old and young, but we cannot tell who ſhall die firſt; therefore be not diſcomforted upon that account, for thou may'ſt die as ſoon as Is if not before me.

p.hi: Would you not cry then Sir, if I ſhould die be fore you?

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: Yes, Pretty Rogue, I ſhould be ſorry for thy death, but thoſe things muſt be left to the diſpoſal of kind Heaven, which orders all things of that Nature in its own due time and ſeaſon.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Say you ſo Sir, but you are older than I, and I very much fear —

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: What doſt thou fear, pretty One? Speak holdly, do not fear to tell me.

p.hi: Why Sir, can't you gueſs.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: Why Yes, fair One, perhaps I may.

p.hi: Pray tell me, what you think then?

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: Well, I believe, thou think'ſt that becauſe I am in years, I may not be capable of thoſe Duties which belong to a new Marriage-bed.

p.hi: Why what are thoſe, Sir?

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: Pretty Innocent: well, thou ſhalt know when we are marry'd, and till then thou muſt reſt contented.

p.hi: Well Sir, I ſhall be contented: But pray till me, if we muſt marry, how I ſhall be maintained, for my Mother will not look after me then.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: Preity Fool, take no care for that: I have got more Gold and Silver than thee and I ſhall ever ſpend whilſt we live, and when we die ſhall leave enough for our Children after us.

p.hi: What muſt we have Children too?

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: Two? Yes, three or four, I'll warrant thee: although I am old in thy eyes, yet I am as youthful and vigorous in thoſe concerns, as a young Man at one and twenty; the enjoyment of thee will make me forget my Age, and become a Boy again.

p.hi: Nay then, I care not Sir, for I ſhall love to ſee you look young.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: Come and kiſs me then, my Nancy.

p.hi: With all my heart Sir. And now I'll ſing you one Verſe of a Song.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: Come let's hear it, Girl.

l.hi: When a young womdn to an old Dotard is wed,
Let her honeſtly live if ſhe can,
'Tis a thouſand to one but with Hornes he'll be ſped,
Iy ſome pretty wanton young man.
Then his wife with diſgrace he ever will ſhame;
But the wiſeſt young Gallants will fiee her from blame.

p.hi: Pray how like you this?

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: Very well, very well, Nanny; Prithee, who taught thee this Song.

p.hi: My Mother Sir, and ſhe ſaid it was a very true one.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: No, no, fair One, it is not true; there is no honeſt woman will wrong her husbands bed, though ſhe have never ſo great temptations.

p.hi: I hope you will not be jealous Sir, I'll promiſe you I will live as honeſtly as ever I can; what would you have me do more?

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: No, no, thou ſay'ſt Well, Girl, I will not be jealous, and I fancy that I ſhall pleaſe thee ſo well, that thou wilt have no cauſe to make me a Cuckold; and we will live together as merry as Cup and Can.

p.hi: Well, what would you have me ſay more, Sir, pray ſpeak, and tell me quickly, for I am weary of this Diſcourſe, I had rather be in action.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: I commend thee, my Lore, and ſo had I too; Well, tell me, then wilt thou have me to be thy Husband?

p.hi: Yes, if you pleaſe, Sir.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.p: Enough, now I have my deſire, and thou ſhalt have thine, I'll warrant thee; now I will go and make preparation againſt too morrow, which ſhall be our VVedding-day; and with this kiſs, at preſent I take leave.

l.hi: All things prepar'd, they marri'd were in haſte,
The Old Man fails, and Cuckold is at laſt.

div.head: DIALOGUE VII. A Merry Dialogue betwixt a young Gentleman and an old Widdow.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: MAdam, the various Reports that go abroad in the World concerning Matrimony, make me ambitious to try an Experiment upon the ſame, and having heard ſo great a Fame of your Ladyſhips good life and converſation, have preſum'd now to tell you, that I am Madam, Your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sir, I can do leſs then give you thanks for your Civility towards me, but I wonder that you ſhould attaque me with the matter of love. I ſuppoſe you underſtand my preſent ſtate and condition, how that of late I have buri'd a good Husband; how therefore can you think that I will admit ſo ſoon of a ſecond addreſs: In the firſt place, you muſt either think that I had but ſmall kindneſs for my former Husband, or etherwiſe you muſt imagine that I am a fond old doting Fool, apt to be carri'd away with every wind of Doctrine that is preach'd to me by every ſimple Ideot, that has onely a proſpect into my Eſtate or Fortune, but has no regard to my perſon. Come, young Gentleman, theſe things won't take.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Madam, I hope I have given you no offence; if I have, I moſt humbly beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: I am no Pope Sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: But Madam you muſt give me leave to tell you then, that if Love can be called an offence, I muſt confeſs that I have offended; for now and evermore I muſt tell you that I love you, and none but you in the whole world; therefore dear Madam, look not ſcornfully upon me, but grant me my humble requeſt; which is to give me love for love.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Why ſure young man you are not in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Yes Madam indeed I am, and ſo you ſhall find me.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Why what would you have me to do, would you have me match my ſelf to a young Boy?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Madam you'll find a luſty Boy of me, methinks I begin to write my ſelf man— being now about twenty; I'll warrant you Madam a good Bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: How ſhall I know that?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Try Widdow, try, there's nothing like it; faith ne'r fear it, I have that you want, come let's grow familiar now.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Are you in earneſt Sir?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Yes by this kiſs I am.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Nay hold you are rude, fie for ſhame; what again?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Again, yes and again and again too.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Why ſure you won't, young man, you'll be tired anon?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: No, no, Widdow, I ſhall never be weary of well-doing.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Do you call this doing well?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Truly I muſt confeſs there is not much action in this; for it is only an invitation to a farther bliſs or happineſs, which the Wits of our Age call enjoyment. Ah VViddow Enjoyment, Enjoyment; that's all.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Prethee what do'ſt thou mean by Enjoyment, I don't underſtand ye?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: VVell well, VViddow, I ſhall ſpeak in plain Engliſh, when you and I are in bed together; however I am fully perſwaded that you know my meaning by Enjoyment, though you have had but little; for I am ſenſible that your Husband was a ſilly feeble Sot, and ſcarce ever ſhew'd you what Enjoyment was; but I VViddow, I'll clear the caſe, and ſhew you what it is immediately, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: VVhy you will not ſurely, will you? methinks you are a little too haſty for me; and yet —

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: And yet I know that cannot well be; for having once but ſmelt of the Spit, you will love a good not flatter you, but proceed according to the old Song, which is this:

lg.head: Song.

l.hi: He that will win a Widdows heart,
Muſt bear up briskly to her:
She loves the lad that's free and ſmart,
And hates the formal woer.
She loves the lad that's free and ſmart,

lg.l: And bates, &c.

sp.p: VVhat think you of this VViddow?

sp.speaker: Widd.
